passages.text: USA | Building Products
Jefferies Industrials Conference: Questions for Building Products & Packaging

To help prep for the Jefferies Industrials Conference on September 3- 4, we have provided a list of questions and the agenda for the 29 companies attending in Building Products and Paper & Packaging. This should provide a real- time read on market dynamics with affordability still challenged and how to be positioned for a rate cut. With consumers still value- seeking, it's affecting demand in packaging, but we've also seen historic amount of capacity coming out.
The conference will be at the Westin Times Square (270 West 43rd St, NYC) and feature presentations, fireside chats, and 1x1/small group meetings with 250+ public and private industrials companies.
For the full list of participating Companies, please see the following: Link.
Please join the Jefferies Industrials team on September 5th for a recap call at 11 AM ET. Please register for the event here [Link] or reach out to your Jefferies sales person to sign up.

Building Products: Housing affordability remains the biggest constraint across both residential new construction and R&R demand. With new home inventories building to decades- high levels YTD, the homebuilders are de- stocking spec inventory, expected to be a drag on activity in 2H. We expect to get a real- time read on demand trends and tariff impacts, as well as other current themes like consolidation in the distribution channel and positioning in potential rate cut backdrop.

Paper & Packaging: Consumers are still value- seeking, which has weighed on packaging volumes and investor sentiment. The conference provides a timely view on demand trends as the impact of tariffs kicks in, promotional activity, and whether the secular dynamics in cans are sustainable. Also, with the containerboard industry taking out \(9\%\) of capacity this year, operating rates could settle in the mid- to- high 90s exiting the year even before factoring in any recovery in demand. We are also keen to get updates on how the transformations are progressing with IP, SW and AMCR.
1x1s: Thursday, September 4th
Attendees: Vic Grizzle, CEO; Chris Calzaretta, CFO; Theresa Womble, Investor Relations

Can you give us a sense on how bidding and quoting activity have trended in July & August, and is your expectation for 2026 volumes to inflect positively in mineral fiber or remain muted? Can you provide us with some color on how demand is trending by end markets, and have you seen any noticeable shift in education, office, and tenant improvement? With the two largest wallboard and ceilings distributors acquired by HD and LOW, how does that impact your business and any risks to your pricing power with the channel getting more consolidated? How do you see them managing the retail and pro side of the business? Growth and margins in AS have really taken off. What are the drivers that have accelerated the performance of AS? How has bidding activity been and how far out are your backlogs for MF and AS? How's the M&A pipeline looking and are there chunkier deals out there like Zahner and 3form? Mix has also been favorable in 1H, how do you see that progressing in 2H and in the medium- to- long- term? Can you provide us with more details on the integration of Zahner and 3form and how they have helped penetrate AS? It's encouraging to see strong demand from WAVE in 2Q and you did a nice job getting a price increase ahead of steel tariffs. Can you talk about how the tariff impacts will impact WAVE in 2H?
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 2:10 PM; Thursday, September 4th; Ambassador II, 2nd Floor
1x1s: Thursday, September 4th
Attendees: Robert Buck, CEO; Rob Kuhns, CFO; PI Aquino, IR

In your revised guidance for 2025, can you remind us what you're assuming for 2H for SF new res, and how orders and bidding have progressed intra quarter? Any color by region and type of customer would helpful as well. There seems to be some greenshoots for MF, when do you see that business turning positive for you? Prang is holding up despite the demand headwinds in residential. Can you talk about how The builders are approaching pricing discussions and your ability to hold price in this type of environment and how you're managing your costs with your suppliers? Mortgage rates have fallen to mid 6s and the Fed has signaled rate cuts could come. At what level do you see it moving the needle and stimulating demand? If we have a few rate cuts this fall, what's the lag before you think you could see an inflection in demand with the builders working down spec home inventory and bottlenecks in land purchases?

In the last 10 years, BLD has delivered \(14\%\) sales CAGR, with \(\mathbb{C}\mathbb{O}\) \(50\%\) driven by M&A. With C&I and most recently the addition of commercial eeting, can M&A sustain that level of contribution to topline and returns you've been able to deliver? How aggressively will you pursue M&A in the current backdrop, how's the pipeline look like where do multiples shake out in roofing and C&I?

Given the LSD share that Progressive has, it's impressive the business is generating \(20\%\) EBITDA margins. It's been a favorable pricing backdrop in commercial roofing the last few years, what's the risk it's over earning and what are they doing differently than its peers where it's able to generate higher margins? In 3- 5 years years, what type of market share do you see BLD commanding in commercial roofing and how big of a business it could be for you?

How much visibility do you have to C&I backlogs and how is bidding activity trending? How are you positioned to capitalize on some of these mega projects whether it's LNG, onshoring, and manufacturing? Are your smaller competitors able to bid and compete on the larger & more complex jobs?

Margins have held up fairly well despite demand headwinds. Can you talk about the actions you are taking on the cost side or other efficiencies you're seeing to offset volume headwinds? What are the key levers you're pulling to maintain when demand is falling?
Recurring revenue is growing as a \(\%\) of total revenue. Can you discuss the MRO piece of the business and how the Progressive acquisition plays into this?
Can you talk about your capital allocation priorities ranked, both short and long- term?
What are you seeing on the cost side, how are the manufacturers managing material pricing, and is there a level of starts where you would expect to see fiberglass deflation?
How has the incremental fiberglass capacity impacted supply / demand dynamics?
What internal KPIs do you use to measure execution and how have you been able to achieve this consistently across your footprint?
\(1\times 1\) s Only: Thursday, September \(4^{\text{th}}\)
Attendees: Peter Beckmann, CFO; Michael Laitkep, Director IR

Now that 2025 expectations have been reset, how are you thinking about the shape of 2026? When do you see the spec home inventory and land development bottleneck flushed out? Mortgage rates have fallen to mid 6s and the Fed has signaled rate cuts could come. At what level do you see it moving the needle and stimulating demand? If we have a few rate cuts this fall, what's the lag before you think you could see an inflection in demand? With MF starts having bottomed and completion comps easing, could MF turn to a source of growth in 2026? There was a lot of discussion in 1H25 of competition in the truss market, especially from smaller players winning business at unsustainable prices. Has this dynamic stabilized and have you seen any business come back? What are you seeing in truss prices overall? You upgraded your long- term gross profit margin guidance to \(30 - 33\%\) . Can you talk about what has structurally changed in the portfolio from when it was a \(25 - 27\%\) gross margin business? Are you earning more money on the commodity business or is it all a mix shift toward value- add products? How is consolidation across the distribution market, as well as at the manufacturer level, impacting your business? Does it change your M&A strategy or product offering? Are you more likely an acquirer or seller?

- How would you characterize the current M&A environment in terms of seller expectations on valuation and targets available? What are some of the areas you find attractive and best opportunities? What are the usual synergies you target with an acquisition?- How much more runway do you see from a mix shift toward value-add products? Can you frame up the magnitude of value-added products expansion embedded in your long-term sales growth targets?- You have been investing in automation. Can you talk about the margin opportunity from automating your plants?- There have been some challenges in the initial stages of your digital offering. What have you learned so far, and what are you doing to further accelerate adoption?
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 2:50 PM; Wednesday, September \(3^{\text{rd}}\) ; Ambassador III, 2nd Floor
1x1s: Wednesday, September \(3^{\text{rd}}\)
Attendees: Craig Kesler, EVP- CFO; Alex Haddock, VP- IR, Strategy & Corporate Development

- The wet weather has weighed on demand, but it was encouraging to see volumes firm up as weather cleared up. How have orders and bidding progressed in August? How are your backlogs looking on a YOY basis, and how far are you bidding out to?- With a few of your European cement competitors listing in the US and now have more headroom on M&A with the multiple expansion, have you seen more competition driving up multiples? Your strategy has been targeted M&A in cement and bolt ons in aggs. With the competitive landscape evolving, does that open the lens for doing something more transformative?- After a very impressive run during the COVID years when you were getting DD cement price increases and mid-years through, pricing has been muted the last two years. Have cement prices peaked and if not, what do you need to see happen for pricing momentum to reaccelerate? How are your inventory levels as well as the market?- You have and are in the process of pursuing several large organic capital investments in TX, Laramie, and Duke. How are these projects progressing, how do you plan on ramping them up in an uneven demand backdrop, and how are these assets positioned strategically in the markets they compete in?- Wallboard demand has been relatively weak given the slowdown in resi activity, but you have handily outperformed the industry the past few quarters. What has been the driver? Are you gaining share due to competitors' difficulty securing cost-efficient syn gyp? Any sharp correction in activity in August as the construction season winds down?- Mortgage rates have fallen to mid 6s and the Fed has signaled rate cuts could come. At what level do you see it moving the needle and stimulating demand? If we have a few rate cuts this fall, what's the lag before you think you could see an inflection in demand, with the builders working down spec home inventory and bottlenecks in land purchases?- With two of the largest wallboard distributors acquired by HD and LOW, how do you see that impacting your business going forward? Historically you've been selective with selling into retail due to less desirable economics, this isn't quite the same, but how do you see HD and LOW running the retail arm vs pro business?- Wallboard pricing has been very resilient in a soft demand environment and during a stretch where builders are looking at means of improving affordability. What's driving the resiliency in pricing and have you seen increased competition in recent months as builders destock spec home inventory?

- Does the OBB impact your capex plans to take advantage of accelerated depreciation? You gave some initial thoughts on your 1Q call on the benefit, but any estimates on potential benefits in FY26/27 and how you plan on deploying the cash?- Operating rates in wallboard have come down given the fall-off in demand and there are pending supply additions. Of the 33bsf of industry capacity, how much do you think is actually operable given syn gyp supply dynamics, and do you expect closures to offset the pending supply additions?
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 10:10 AM; Wednesday, September \(3^{\text{rd}}\) ; Ambassador III, 2nd Floor
1x1s: Wednesday, September \(3^{\text{rd}}\)
Attendees: Jon Baksh, CFO; Nicholas Fink, CEO; Leigh Avsec, Executive VP; Curtis Worthington, IR

- How have your orders and POS progressed in the quarter? There have been some mixed data points, with HD & LOW calling an improvement in July & greenshoots in big ticket R&R, but a large siding manufacturer calling for a much softer new construction & R&R market.- Mortgage rates have fallen to mid 6s and the Fed has signaled rate cuts could come. At what level do you see it moving the needle and stimulating demand? If we have a few rate cuts this fall, what's the lag before you think you could see an inflection in demand, and do you need existing home sales to turn?- Can you walk us through what you're seeing on the competitive landscape front in water innovation, there seems to be more share movement in recent years? It was encouraging to hear you've seen some wins with national homebuilders, expanded offerings for retail and e-comm, and new insurance partnerships with Flo.- Walk us through the connected products initiative? It seems like you're finding a broader opportunity set and signing up a lot of insurance providers, but converting that to sales have been a little slower. Also, what are you seeing in the newly launched subscription model for Flo and how much do you expect that to contribute to your connected LT targets?- How have you managed pricing for plumbing between wholesale, retail, and ecom, and how are the increases implemented? Retail has been firm on not taking price, does that create conflicts between the channels?- What's the latest view on tariffs and the impact? The copper component piece was a bit fluid at the time when you reported results, any update there? How have the price increases been received, what elasticity trends are you observing, and how are the mitigation efforts have come along?- Any update on dumping duties on fiberglass doors and have you seen any new wins? Have tariffs had a dampening impact on some of some of the inferior products coming in from Asia in security?- Now that you have time to reflect on the Assa deal, what are some of the puts and takes? Results in the security segment have been uneven and we haven't seen the type of growth expected. What are you doing to help drive an improvement in results in the business?- How's the corporate headquarters relocation and centralization coming along? Give us an update and the strategic rational, there's been some concerns it could lead to disruption in the business.- How are you managing input cost volatility, particularly in raw materials and logistics?- What progress have you made on structural cost initiatives or automation that could improve long-term efficiency?
1x1s Only: Wednesday, September 3rd
Attendees: Michael Miller, EVP & CFO; Jeff Hire, President of External Affairs; Darren Hicks, Managing Director, IR

- What drove IBP's market outperformance in 2Q25, and how sustainable are these drivers given current market conditions? How is IBP adjusting its operations or sales strategy to mitigate the impact of softer SF starts this year?- How much impact are you seeing from builder de-stocking, and when do you expect inventories to be more balanced?- With the Fed signaling rate cuts, how quickly do you think this could impact your business? Is there an interest rate threshold you see demand snapping back more meaningfully?- With a target of \(100 million in annual revenue from acquisitions, what criteria are guiding your M&A decisions, and why has acquisition activity slowed & how's the pipeline? What's your appetite for more transformative deals and venturing into distribution or other contracting type businesses?- Your MF business has been delivering solid results despite starts headwinds. How is CQ contributing to the strength there, and how do you think about the impact of recent improvement in MF starts trends flowing through to your business? How is IBP positioning itself to capture further share in this segment?- What is driving the strong growth in heavy commercial, and how do you plan to scale this success across other regions or segments?- Pricing is holding up despite the demand headwinds in residential. Can you talk about how the builders are approaching pricing discussions and your ability to hold price in this type of environment?- What's your approach to balancing price increases with competitive positioning in the current environment?- What are you seeing on the cost side, how are the manufacturers managing material pricing, and is there a level where you would expect to see fiberglass deflation?- How has the incremental fiberglass capacity impacted supply / demand dynamics?- With adjusted gross margins holding above your 32-34% target, how are you thinking about a sustainable gross margin level for the business?- What are the primary levers IBP is using to protect or expand margins in a potentially slower demand environment?
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 1:30 PM; Wednesday, September 3rd; Ambassador III 2nd Floor
1x1s: Wednesday, September 3rd
Attendees: Anselm Wong, CFO; Sara Macioch, IR
- Can you provide some color on what your customers are telling you and how your orders & backlogs have progressed in July and August? Have you seen any uptick in project delays?

- With the Fed signaling a September rate cut, how much do rates need to fall and how quickly do you expect the impact to flow through your business? Rates impact your non-institutional customers and the end consumer as well, right?- Give us an update on what you're seeing from a competitive landscape standpoint? I would imagine some of your smaller competitors aren't as sophisticated from a procurement standpoint, and tariffs have made it challenging. Have you been able to gain share and do you see opportunities to buy some distressed assets on the cheap?- Remind us how you approach your steel purchases and how far hedged are you? What is your current strategy for steel procurement for 2H25 and 2026 and pricing? Can you raise prices in 2026 in this current demand backdrop with steel prices moving higher?- It's encouraging that sales in your commercial business turned positive in 2Q on a YOY basis. The end markets are still pretty squishy, can you unpack what's driving the growth?- Can you give us some insight into how your remix business is doing and what's driving the increase in backlog? Have you lapped the retail conversions yet, and are you seeing any recovery?- Growth in NOK has been pretty solid. How's the acceptance been for your new offering? Do you expect to reach the 500K units threshold in 2026 when it becomes a needle mover in EBITDA?- What's your current priority on capital allocation between M&A and buybacks? How's the pipeline in M&A?- Under the current liquidity backdrop, can you talk more on your visibility on the non-institutional client side vs. the institutional side?- Pricing pressure in 1H looked more manageable than feared. Can you provide some color on what you're seeing in self-storage and commercial?- In a weaker demand backdrop, what are some of the self-help levers you have to sustain or drive margins higher?
Dinner: Tuesday, September 2nd
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 9:30 AM; Wednesday, September 3rd; Ambassador III, 2nd Floor
1x1s: Wednesday, September 3rd
Attendees: Aaron Erter, CEO; Rachel Wilson, CFO; Joe Ahlersmeyer, IR; Grant Smith, IR

- For many that are new to JHX and the siding market, can you give us some overview of the company, the industry structure, LT growth algo, and your go to market strategy?- Can you talk about early insights from the first few months of integration with Azek? What has the initial customer response been? Can you walk us through the different drivers in increasing penetration and conversion in R&R in the Midwest and NE? How do you accelerate the cross-selling opportunity now with Azek in the fold?- How are you leveraging your sales and contractor network to drive cross selling? Are you re-aligning any KPIs for sales or your contractor loyalty program? How do you convert new contractors, dealers, and distributors?- Appreciating it's a dynamic environment out there, your updated FY26 guide signals a sharp correction compared to your initial outlook for the year, and your largest hard siding competitor is calling for a more stable backdrop. Can you talk about the biggest changes to your outlook, and how much line of sight do you have? Do your large builder customers give you updates on their
build schedule over the year, and how far out do your channel partners signal on orders & how they plan to manage inventory?

- With the channel and builders destocking spec home inventory especially at this point of the season, it's hard to parse out the noise, but we have investors asking if the material conversion & penetration story for fiber cement in the US has peaked. Can you share with us your view in that journey and how JHX drives value to the homeowner and contractor to drive material conversion?- How are you approaching growth initiatives in the new construction market in the current backdrop? With affordability the biggest constraint and home builders hyper-focused on costs, are you seeing a NT shift away from more premium hard siding to vinyl? How are you addressing the cost differential between fiber cement and alternatives like vinyl?- Pricing held up in the quarter despite volume headwinds. Have you seen increased price competition and how are you approaching pricing in a softer demand backdrop whether its promotions or differentiated pricing by channel? How are price spread vs your product vs other premium hard siding and vinyl stack up currently? Is the spread wider than historical standards?- Your channel partners started de-stocking in F1Q and your guide assumes a similar pace the next 2 quarters. At this pace, where do you see channel inventory levels exiting this calendar year? Well below normal or fairly in line given demand headwinds? Given your service levels, do you expect the channel to keep inventories at a historically lower level?- Historically, you've noted new construction has been about 35% of your sales in NA Fiber cement. Given your wins with the large builders, how has that mix evolved since your revised outlook seems to indicate much more sensitivity to new construction and with the large production builders.- How do you manage the business through a softer environment? Investing in the business, fixed vs variable costs, capacity considerations?- Appreciating different geographic / channel / customer mix, how can investors get comfortable that fiber cement isn't losing share to engineered wood and vinyl?
1x1s Only: Wednesday, September 3rd
Attendees: Jon Nudi, CEO; Robin Zondervan, IR

- How have your orders and POS progressed in the quarter? There have been some mixed data points, with HD & LOW calling an improvement in July & greenshoots in big ticket R&R, but a large siding manufacturer calling for a much softer new construction & R&R market.- Jon, as you look at putting your stamp on MAS under your leadership, any notable shifts in strategy and opportunities to further enhance profitable growth?- Jon, given your CPG background, you've pointed on opportunities on digital and e-commerce. What specific initiatives are underway, and how do you measure ROI?- What's the latest view on tariffs and the impact? The copper component piece was a bit fluid at the time when you reported results, any update there? How have the price increases been received, what elasticity trends are you observing, and how are the mitigation efforts have come along?- How have you managed pricing for plumbing between wholesale, retail, and ecom, and how are the increases implemented? Retail has been firm on not taking price, does that create conflicts between the channels?- With DIY paint a lower growth category, what new adjacencies or markets are you looking to tap into organically or inorganically? Any new initiatives with HD that could be a meaningful source of growth the next 3-5 years on the horizon?

- Can you walk us through what you're seeing on the competitive landscape front in plumbing, there seems to be more share movement in recent years?- Plumbing Products grew 5% while Decorative Architectural declined 12%. How are you addressing the performance gap between these segments?- Delta Faucet and other premium brands outperformed. How are you balancing price versus volume growth in these categories?- What new product innovations are planned for 2026–2027, and how do they align with evolving consumer preferences in home improvement?- With R&R spending projected to decline, how are you adjusting your channel strategy or product mix to maintain growth?- Are you seeing shifts in DIY vs. PRO demand, and how is that influencing your marketing and distribution priorities?- How do you evaluate the trade-off between buybacks and bolt-on acquisitions in the current environment?- What's your approach to balance sheet optimization and capital deployment?
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 10:10 AM; Thursday, September 4th; Ambassador II, 2nd Floor
1x1s: Thursday, September 4th
Attendees: Jim Brunk, CFO; Nick Manthey, Division CFO - FNA & IR

- Several of your competitors have announced price increases for both imported and domestically produced products for Sept/Oct, have you announced any increases? What products were the increases for and does it cover both imported and domestically produced products?- How have your orders progressed, and the channel managed inventory in the quarter? There have been some mixed data points, with HD & LOW calling an improvement in July & greenshoots in big ticket R&R, but a large siding manufacturer calling for a much softer new construction & R&R market.- Mortgage rates have fallen to mid 6s and the Fed has signaled rate cuts could come. At what level do you see it moving the needle and stimulating demand? If we have a few rate cuts this fall, what's the lag before you think you could see an inflection in demand, and do you need existing home sales to turn?- You've taken a lot of costs out and streamlined your business the last few years, if we get a recovery next year, what type of operating leverage do you have in the business? There was a 12-month stretch during the pandemic where your incremental EBITDA margins were in the high 40s / mid 50s. How are you set up this time around, and are there any bottlenecks like labor or need to start up lines to be able to support the demand?- Can you provide some color on the pricing environment? Where are you seeing the most pressure, and when do you anticipate prices will bottom? Have you seen any upwards pricing momentum outside of tariff related movement?- As a domestic manufacturer, have the tariffs led to any new looks with line reviews in retail and additional shelf space wins? The Chinese had the first mover advantage on LVT, but how is MHK positioned now from a cost and quality standpoint, as well as laminate as a substitute?- Your balance sheet remains strong, what are your capital deployment priorities and appetite to step up buybacks with your shares at current levels vs M&A? How's the M&A pipeline looking and
if there were anything on the larger side, can you give us a sense in what products and markets do you see the best opportunities?

Mix has been a tailwind recently. What dynamics are playing out that you are able to mix up, and how sustainable is the positive mix? Any signs of a commercial slowdown with several macro indicators pointing to slowing activity?- Can you talk about some of the investments you've made on the growth side whether its LVT, quartz countertops, or laminate, how the reception has been, and your go-to-market strategy?- What are you seeing across input costs, and how should we think about price/cost dynamics in 2H25 & 2026?
Presentation (Fireside Chat): 12:10 PM; Thursday, September 4th; Majestic II, 5th Floor
1x1s: Thursday, September 4th
Attendees: Ward Nye, Chairman, President & CEO; Michael Petro, SVP, CFO; Bob Cardin, SVP, Controller and CAO; Jacklyn Rooker, Director, IR

- In a flat to down LSD volume environment, it's impressive you're getting 6-7% of price in aggregates. Can you give us some color on mid-years and more importantly, the pricing momentum heading into 2026? How sustainable is this new level of pricing looking out the next few years as inflation moderates?- The wet weather has weighed on demand, but it was encouraging to see volumes snap back in July in the DD range. How have orders and bidding progressed in August? How are your backlogs looking on a YOY basis, and how far are you bidding out to?- You noted that the Quikrete aggregate assets are below the company average from both an ASP and profitability standpoint. Can you give us a sense how much below, and the timeline to bring those inline with the corporate average? What are some of the operational improvements you can make with these assets to improve profitability?- Following the Quikrete asset swap, you're now in the Pacific Northwest and VA, two markets you highlighted as a focus area. Do you have critical mass in these markets, and the potential M&A targets, are they chunkier in nature or more bolt-ons? How's the M&A pipeline looking?- Your ability to grow your gross profit per ton in a dynamic backdrop the last few years has been impressive and cost control YTD has been notable. What are some of the continuous improvement efforts you have embarked on, the runway, and with inflation normalizing, is LSD cost/ton inflation a reasonable target over the medium term?- Do you have any initial thoughts on a new Federal Transportation Bill for FY27 on funding lending levels and next steps from Congress? Assuming we get a bill before the expiration of IIJA, how do you see the funding rippling through your volumes? Is there risk of an air pocket in 2028 given the lag in dispersing the funding?- With the Premier Magnesia acquisition, you are the largest supplier of Magnesia in the US. What new markets does this acquisition open-up, what synergies can you capture, and what other capital investments could you make to further grow this business? How do imports play a role in this market and pricing?- You have sounded more constructive on private non-res activity the last two calls. Warehouse was one of your biggest end markets in non res, how's the bidding activity & backlogs looking, do you see it inflecting positive in 2026? You've been upbeat on data centers, utilities to build out the AI infrastructure, and perhaps onshoring. These categories tend to be more aggregates
intensive, how much of private non res does it represent today, and how meaningful do you see it becoming in a few years?
Does the OBBB impact your capex plans to take advantage of accelerated depreciation? You gave some initial thoughts on your 2Q call on the benefit, but any estimates on potential benefits in FY26/27?
1x1s Only: Wednesday, September 3rd
Attendees: Brian Chambers, Chair & CEO; Bill Sparrow, IR

- Your results have been very strong over the last 5 years, but a lot of the growth was anchored by pricing and cost-out initiatives. As you look out to achieving your 2028 targets, why are you confident with the pivot to grow faster than the market? You're not guiding to meaningful price in 2028 targets, but is positive price cost a lever still available?- Price cost has been a driver for margin expansion in roofing. With roofing margins in the low 30s and more capacity coming online, do you have the ability to sustain a positive price cost spread, or is it more neutral? The low end of your LT margin target for roofing is 27%, what needs to happen to get there and are you assuming a negative price cost spread?- Implicit in your 2028 targets, you're assuming roofing demand for the industry has peaked, so how do you see OC growing in that backdrop, and why do you see margins structurally re-basing higher at the 30% level?- You have had DD volume declines in your NA resi insulation business, and inventory levels for SF seems elevated. With that backdrop, the fiberglass insulation mkt feels more wobbly. What actions can you take to help balance S/D in the near-to-medium term, and do you see risk prices falls?- With HD and LOW getting into the pro channel and QXO looking to consolidate the channel as well, how has that impacted your business and your relationship with the companies? Risk on pricing? Opportunity to sell a more bundled offering to the channel? Has your go-to-market strategy evolved?- With Amrize now listed in the US and Kingspan looking to get bigger here as well, how do you see that impacting the industry? The focus the next few years is returning \(\) 2\$ bill of cash back to shareholders, but where does pursuing adjacencies stack up in terms of priorities over the next 5 years?- You've had a lot of success building out the contractor network in roofing, how has that translated in your efforts in doors, and what are the early learnings? You're rolling out this bundling and loyalty program to drive cross-selling, can you give us some color on where you see the biggest opportunities & feedback?- There's more uncertainty with US housing in the near term, but where are you in the cycle in your commercial business in the US and Europe? How have margins & demand held up in recent years, along with a moderate recession? How are you positioned with the war between Russia / Ukraine ending?- What are you seeing on the pricing front in doors? JELD is calling increased price competition from the smaller private players.- Organic volumes for both Masonite and JELD in the last 5 years have been quite muted and lagging the end markets. Is doors a secularly challenged category or have the converters been taking share?
Presentation (Hybrid): 2:10 PM; Wednesday, September \(3^{rd}\) ; Ambassador III, \(2^{nd}\) Floor
1x1s: Wednesday, September \(3^{rd}\)
Attendees: Tim Larson, CEO; Laurie Hough, CFO

You called out slower activity in the independent retail dealers and pockets of weakness in the South on your earnings call. Curious what type of trends have you seen in July and August? You've made investments in ecom and expanded into captive retail channel with investments you've made in Regional Homes and Iseman Homes to expand your reach and improve the home buyer experience. Anyway to quantify the impact it had on growth and profitability? What inning are you with that process? What % of your sales is in captive retail, and where do you see it reaching in 3- 5 years? Mondi is an income & value recovery play over the next 1- 2yrs, with compelling risk/reward skew post self- off, with shares in our view at close your eyes levels. The sentiment & narrative on the stock could shift quickly into 2026, and Mondi is well positioned to see strong EBITDA & FCF upside, when packaging ultimately recovers given its low- cost & well invested asset base, returns on major capex & M&A delivering accretive growth.

- Would Mondi consider providing medium term or annual EBITDA guidance like US peers IP/SW?- Would Mondi consider pulling back €650-750m capex (D&A of €500m) and to support shareholder returns and buying back shares given your discount to intrinsic value?- Well positioned to see strong EBITDA & FCF upside, when packaging ultimately recovers given its low-cost & well invested asset base - Where are in the cycle and what would be the key positive catalysts into 2026?- Building & construction exposure (15-20%) - how are you positioned for see recovery?- Germany exposure (c20%) - Would you benefit from Germany fiscal stimulus-led demand?- S/D dynamics and pricing: How you see the supply & demand per division: 1) Containerboard & boxes; 2) Sack paper for bags- What is management's view on the timing and magnitude of industry capacity closures needed to rebalance the EU board market?- Mondi is global #1 in sack & bags - do you think your market position is underappreciated by investors? Does this division deserve a higher multiple vs corrugated?- Strategy & Capital Allocation Priorities: What is your strategy by division and your capital allocation priorities by division?

- Demand & pricing: Can you give us more colour on your 2H25-2026 order books and outlook for your key end markets?- Can you frame how you see current volume levels in corrugated & flexible packaging vs pre-Covid?- Plastic vs Paper - do you still see this as supportive medium term? What are the near-term challenges given plastic substitution initiatives have slowed (inflation) & discount retailers share gains (use more plastic in their packaging mix).- M&A - How might the transatlantic M&A impact Mondi? Are you sub scale in boxes?- Cost inflation - what are you seeing in wood, logistics, energy etc?- Structural Cost Advantages & Barriers to Entry: How do you think about your asset base and why is your focus on structurally cost-advantaged integrated virgin paper mills (75-80% of capacity in lowest two cost quartiles)?- What do you consider are the barriers to entry & key advantages in: 1) Corrugated Packaging (c30-40% EBITDA); 2) Flexible Packaging (c50% EBITDA)
- Close your Eyes Levels- Watch the Video- Underappreciated Flexible Packaging Business- Wrap Stars: trends in European P&P Prices

Hold - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of plus \(15\%\) or minus \(10\%\) within a 12- month period. Underperform - Describes securities that we expect to provide a total return (price appreciation plus yield) of minus \(10\%\) or less within a 12- month period. The expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) for Buy rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) is \(20\%\) or more within a 12- month period as these companies are typically more volatile than the overall stock market. For Hold rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is plus or minus \(20\%\) within a 12- month period. For Underperform rated securities with an average security price consistently below \(10\) , the expected total return (price appreciation plus yield) is minus \(20\%\) or less within a 12- month period.
